metadata.Name: POLYGLOT-NER
metadata.Description: POLYGLOT-NER is a massively multilingual Named Entity Recognition system that builds annotators for 40 major languages using Wikipedia and Freebase. It does not require human-annotated datasets or language-specific resources.
metadata.Paper Title: POLYGLOT-NER: Massive Multilingual Named Entity Recognition
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Stony Brook University
metadata.Abstract: The increasing diversity of languages used on the web introduces a new level of complexity to Information Retrieval (IR) systems. We can no longer assume that textual content is written in one language or even the same language family. In this paper, we demonstrate how to build massive multilingual annotators with minimal human expertise and intervention. We describe a system that builds Named Entity Recognition (NER) annotators for 40 major languages using Wikipedia and Freebase. Our approach does not require NER human annotated datasets or language specific resources like treebanks, parallel corpora, and orthographic rules. The novelty of approach lies therein-using only language agnostic techniques, while achieving competitive performance. Our work addresses these drawbacks by relying on language-independent techniques. We use neural word embeddings, Wikipedia link structure, and Freebase attributes to automatically construct NER annotators for 40 major languages.
